cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
In 1976, which gymnast scored 7 maximum scores of 10 as she won three gold medals, one silver and one bronze?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To identify the gymnast who scored 7 maximum scores of 10 in 1976 and won three gold medals, one silver, and one bronze, we can analyze the context of gymnastics during that time. The 1976 Summer Olympics were held in Montreal, Canada, and were notable for the performances of several gymnasts.

Among the prominent gymnasts of the 1976 Olympics was Nadia Comăneci, a Romanian gymnast. She is famously known for being the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 in Olympic history. During the 1976 Olympics, she achieved this feat multiple times, totaling seven perfect 10 scores throughout the competition. 

Nadia Comăneci won three gold medals in the individual all-around, balance beam, and uneven bars, along with a silver medal in the team competition and a bronze medal on the floor exercise. 

Given this information, it is clear that Nadia Comăneci is the gymnast in question.

Answer:
Nadia Comăneci

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
In 1976, which gymnast scored 7 maximum scores of 10 as she won three gold medals, one silver and one bronze?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['While training for the World Championships in Tokyo, Sacramone tore her Achilles tendon. She returned to the U.S. immediately for surgery. However, the team kept her name on the roster, and she was given a gold medal despite not competing. This gave her the most World Championships medals of any female American gymnast, with ten. Simone Biles would break that record in 2015.\n', 'There were only 4 routines left for each gymnast to compete. With 2 down and 2 to go the places were now: Gnauck 1st, Davydova 2nd, Shaposhnikova and Comaneci joint 3rd. Nadia Comăneci then scored a 10 on bars, the only gymnast to receive a perfect score that night. (It was her first perfect score on bars in a major competition since the 1976 Olympics). Neil Admur, New York Times, 25 July 1980, A17, "The drama on the final rotation added to the suspense. Miss Gnauck was second among the 9 gymnasts on the vault, Miss Davydova seventh on the bars and Miss Comaneci eight on the beam". Maxi Gnauck held the lead until her last routine when she vaulted insecurely. She scored 9.7, on a vault with a start value of 9.9, the same as she had scored for this vault at 1979 European Championships in Denmark and 79 World Championships in United States. Barry Lorge, Washington Post, 25 July 1980, p.\xa09, "Gnauck, first of the contenders up in the fourth and final rotation. Her first vault looked good but was too safe : 9.7. She knew she had to do better but she buckled on the landing of her second vault". Peter Aykroyd, International Gymnastics : Sport, Art or Science ?, 1987, p.\xa068, "She went into the all-round finals with a slight lead, but weak vaulting lost her this advantage".\n', 'A perfect 10 is a score of 10.00 for a single routine in artistic gymnastics, which was once thought to be unattainable—particularly at the Olympic Games—under the code of points set by the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG). It is generally recognized that the first person to score a perfect 10 at the Olympic Games was Romanian Nadia Comăneci, at the 1976 Games in Montreal. Other women who accomplished this feat at the Olympics include Nellie Kim, also in 1976, Mary Lou Retton in 1984, Daniela Silivaș and Yelena Shushunova in 1988, and Lavinia Miloșovici in 1992. The first man to score a perfect 10 is considered to be Alexander Dityatin, at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow. (However, in the 1924 Paris Olympics, 22 men achieved a mark of 10 in rope-climbing, with one Albert Séguin getting a second 10 in the sidehorse vault, events that are no longer part of artistic gymnastics.)\n', 'Maria Kondratyevna Gorokhovskaya (, ; 17 October 1921 – 22 July 2001) was a Soviet gymnast of Jewish descent. At the 1952 Summer Olympics, she won seven medals, the most medals won by any woman in a single Olympics.\n', 'Larisa Semyonovna Latynina (, ; née Diriy; born 27 December 1934) is a former Soviet artistic gymnast from southern Ukrainian SSR. Between 1956 and 1964 she won 14 individual Olympic medals and four team medals. She holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals by a gymnast, male or female, with 9. Her total of 18 Olympic medals was a record for 48 years. She held the record for individual event medals with 14 for 52 years. She is credited with helping to establish the Soviet Union as a dominant force in gymnastics.\n', 'Shannon Miller, who competed at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics, won seven total Olympic medals, the most of any American female gymnast. She won five medals in 1992 and added two more in 1996. Dominique Dawes competed at the 1992, 1996, and 2000 Olympics, winning four medals. Miller and Dawes were both members of the "Magnificent Seven", the 1996 team that became the first American squad to win the team all-around gold medal at the Olympics. The competition was highlighted by Kerri Strug sticking a vault while injured to ensure the U.S. victory.\n', 'Almost a quarter of all the medals and 25 of the gold ones were won in gymnastics, with Olympic and sport icon Nadia Comăneci becoming the first gymnast ever to score a perfect ten in an Olympic event at the 1976 Summer Olympics. \n', "She won all six rhythmic gymnastics events included as part of the gymnastics program at the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne. She joined Graham Smith (1978, Edmonton), Susie O'Neill (1998, Kuala Lumpur) and Ian Thorpe (2002, Manchester) as the only competitors to win six gold medals at a single Commonwealth Games.\n", "Czechoslovakia's Věra Čáslavská won 11 total Olympic medals, the second-most of any female gymnast. She won one in 1960, four in 1964, and six in 1968. She won the individual all-around golds in 1964 and 1968. Nadia Comăneci, who competed for Romania in 1976 and 1980, won nine medals. In 1976, she became the first gymnast to earn a perfect 10 and eventually achieved that mark seven times during the Games. She also won the individual all-around gold that year.\n", "The Magnificent Seven was the 1996 United States Olympic women's gymnastics team that won the first ever gold medal for the United States in the women's team competition at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The seven members of the team were Shannon Miller, Dominique Moceanu, Dominique Dawes, Kerri Strug, Amy Chow, Amanda Borden, and Jaycie Phelps. Miller, Dawes and Chow also won individual medals in Atlanta. The team is perhaps best known for Strug sticking the landing of a vault to clinch the gold medal while injured.\n"]

To identify the gymnast who scored 7 maximum scores of 10 in 1976 and won three gold medals, one silver, and one bronze, we need to analyze the context of gymnastics during that time, particularly focusing on the 1976 Summer Olympics held in Montreal, Canada. This event was significant for several gymnasts, but one stood out due to her remarkable achievements.

**Key Points:**

1. **Nadia Comăneci's Historic Performance**:
   - Nadia Comăneci, a Romanian gymnast, is renowned for being the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 in Olympic history. This groundbreaking achievement occurred during the 1976 Olympics, where she scored a perfect 10 a total of seven times throughout the competition.
   - Her perfect scores were achieved in various events, showcasing her exceptional skills and precision.

2. **Medal Count**:
   - During the 1976 Olympics, Comăneci won three gold medals in the individual all-around, balance beam, and uneven bars. Additionally, she secured a silver medal in the team competition and a bronze medal on the floor exercise. This impressive medal haul highlights her dominance in the sport during that Olympic cycle.

3. **Significance of Perfect Scores**:
   - A perfect score of 10.00 is a significant milestone in artistic gymnastics, once thought to be unattainable, especially at the Olympic level. Comăneci's achievement of seven perfect scores not only set a record but also changed the perception of what was possible in gymnastics.

4. **Comparative Context**:
   - While other gymnasts, such as Nellie Kim, also scored perfect tens in 1976, Comăneci's seven perfect scores distinguished her as a pioneering figure in the sport. Her performances contributed to the evolution of gymnastics and inspired future generations of gymnasts.

5. **Impact on the Sport**:
   - Comăneci's achievements at the 1976 Olympics helped to elevate the profile of gymnastics globally. She is credited with helping to establish Romania as a powerhouse in the sport and has remained an iconic figure in gymnastics history.

### Conclusion:

Her historic performance not only defined her career but also left an indelible mark on the sport of gymnastics.

### Answer:
Nadia Comăneci

**Expert Discussion on Nadia Comăneci's Achievements in 1976**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
Nadia Comăneci is a pivotal figure in gymnastics history, particularly for her performance at the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal. She was the first gymnast to score a perfect 10.0, achieving this remarkable feat seven times during the Games. This not only showcased her exceptional talent but also revolutionized the sport, setting a new standard for excellence. Her performance led her to win three gold medals, one silver, and one bronze, making her the standout athlete of those Olympics.

**Expert 2: Sports Performance Analyst**
From a performance analysis perspective, Comăneci's ability to score multiple perfect tens is unprecedented. The passages highlight that she achieved her first perfect score on the uneven bars, which was a significant moment in gymnastics history. The fact that she maintained such high performance across various apparatuses under the pressure of the Olympics speaks volumes about her mental fortitude and technical skill. This achievement not only earned her medals but also solidified her legacy as a gymnast who changed the perception of what was possible in the sport.

**Expert 3: Cultural Impact Scholar**
Comăneci's impact transcends her athletic achievements. She became a symbol of excellence and a source of national pride for Romania during a time when the country was under a communist regime. Her success at the Olympics inspired a generation of gymnasts and contributed to the global popularity of gymnastics as a competitive sport. The passages indicate that her performances were not just about winning medals; they were about breaking barriers and inspiring future athletes, particularly women in sports.

**Expert 4: Technical Rules Expert**
From a technical standpoint, the scoring system in gymnastics has evolved significantly since 1976. At that time, a perfect score was considered nearly unattainable, and Comăneci's ability to achieve it repeatedly challenged the norms of the sport. The passages mention that she scored a perfect 10 on multiple occasions, which was a groundbreaking achievement. This raises questions about how scoring has changed over the years and how Comăneci's performances influenced the development of scoring criteria in gymnastics.

**Points of Agreement and Disagreement:**
All experts agree on the significance of Comăneci's achievements and her role in transforming gymnastics. They acknowledge her technical skill and the cultural impact of her success. However, there is a divergence in focus: while some emphasize her athletic prowess and the technical aspects of her routines, others highlight her cultural significance and the broader implications of her success for women in sports.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
Nadia Comăneci's performance at the 1976 Olympics is a multifaceted topic that encompasses her groundbreaking athletic achievements, the evolution of gymnastics scoring, and her cultural impact. Her ability to score seven perfect tens not only set a new standard in gymnastics but also inspired future generations of athletes. The discussion reveals that her legacy is not solely defined by her medals but also by her role as a trailblazer in a sport that continues to evolve. This comprehensive understanding underscores the importance of recognizing both the technical and cultural dimensions of athletic success. 

In conclusion, Comăneci's achievements in 1976 serve as a landmark moment in sports history, illustrating how individual excellence can influence a sport's trajectory and inspire societal change.

Passages:
['While training for the World Championships in Tokyo, Sacramone tore her Achilles tendon. She returned to the U.S. immediately for surgery. However, the team kept her name on the roster, and she was given a gold medal despite not competing. This gave her the most World Championships medals of any female American gymnast, with ten. Simone Biles would break that record in 2015.
', 'There were only 4 routines left for each gymnast to compete. With 2 down and 2 to go the places were now: Gnauck 1st, Davydova 2nd, Shaposhnikova and Comaneci joint 3rd. Nadia Comăneci then scored a 10 on bars, the only gymnast to receive a perfect score that night. (It was her first perfect score on bars in a major competition since the 1976 Olympics). Neil Admur, New York Times, 25 July 1980, A17, "The drama on the final rotation added to the suspense. Miss Gnauck was second among the 9 gymnasts on the vault, Miss Davydova seventh on the bars and Miss Comaneci eight on the beam". Maxi Gnauck held the lead until her last routine when she vaulted insecurely. She scored 9.7, on a vault with a start value of 9.9, the same as she had scored for this vault at 1979 European Championships in Denmark and 79 World Championships in United States. Barry Lorge, Washington Post, 25 July 1980, p.\xa09, "Gnauck, first of the contenders up in the fourth and final rotation. Her first vault looked good but was too safe : 9.7. She knew she had to do better but she buckled on the landing of her second vault". Peter Aykroyd, International Gymnastics : Sport, Art or Science ?, 1987, p.\xa068, "She went into the all-round finals with a slight lead, but weak vaulting lost her this advantage".
', 'A perfect 10 is a score of 10.00 for a single routine in artistic gymnastics, which was once thought to be unattainable—particularly at the Olympic Games—under the code of points set by the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG). It is generally recognized that the first person to score a perfect 10 at the Olympic Games was Romanian Nadia Comăneci, at the 1976 Games in Montreal. Other women who accomplished this feat at the Olympics include Nellie Kim, also in 1976, Mary Lou Retton in 1984, Daniela Silivaș and Yelena Shushunova in 1988, and Lavinia Miloșovici in 1992. The first man to score a perfect 10 is considered to be Alexander Dityatin, at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow. (However, in the 1924 Paris Olympics, 22 men achieved a mark of 10 in rope-climbing, with one Albert Séguin getting a second 10 in the sidehorse vault, events that are no longer part of artistic gymnastics.)
', 'Maria Kondratyevna Gorokhovskaya (, ; 17 October 1921 – 22 July 2001) was a Soviet gymnast of Jewish descent. At the 1952 Summer Olympics, she won seven medals, the most medals won by any woman in a single Olympics.
', 'Larisa Semyonovna Latynina (, ; née Diriy; born 27 December 1934) is a former Soviet artistic gymnast from southern Ukrainian SSR. Between 1956 and 1964 she won 14 individual Olympic medals and four team medals. She holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals by a gymnast, male or female, with 9. Her total of 18 Olympic medals was a record for 48 years. She held the record for individual event medals with 14 for 52 years. She is credited with helping to establish the Soviet Union as a dominant force in gymnastics.
', 'Shannon Miller, who competed at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics, won seven total Olympic medals, the most of any American female gymnast. She won five medals in 1992 and added two more in 1996. Dominique Dawes competed at the 1992, 1996, and 2000 Olympics, winning four medals. Miller and Dawes were both members of the "Magnificent Seven", the 1996 team that became the first American squad to win the team all-around gold medal at the Olympics. The competition was highlighted by Kerri Strug sticking a vault while injured to ensure the U.S. victory.
', 'Almost a quarter of all the medals and 25 of the gold ones were won in gymnastics, with Olympic and sport icon Nadia Comăneci becoming the first gymnast ever to score a perfect ten in an Olympic event at the 1976 Summer Olympics. 
', "She won all six rhythmic gymnastics events included as part of the gymnastics program at the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne. She joined Graham Smith (1978, Edmonton), Susie O'Neill (1998, Kuala Lumpur) and Ian Thorpe (2002, Manchester) as the only competitors to win six gold medals at a single Commonwealth Games.
", "Czechoslovakia's Věra Čáslavská won 11 total Olympic medals, the second-most of any female gymnast. She won one in 1960, four in 1964, and six in 1968. She won the individual all-around golds in 1964 and 1968. Nadia Comăneci, who competed for Romania in 1976 and 1980, won nine medals. In 1976, she became the first gymnast to earn a perfect 10 and eventually achieved that mark seven times during the Games. She also won the individual all-around gold that year.
", "The Magnificent Seven was the 1996 United States Olympic women's gymnastics team that won the first ever gold medal for the United States in the women's team competition at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The seven members of the team were Shannon Miller, Dominique Moceanu, Dominique Dawes, Kerri Strug, Amy Chow, Amanda Borden, and Jaycie Phelps. Miller, Dawes and Chow also won individual medals in Atlanta. The team is perhaps best known for Strug sticking the landing of a vault to clinch the gold medal while injured.
"]

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding Nadia Comăneci's achievements at the 1976 Olympics. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its implications for causal reasoning and logical inference:

### Extracted Information:
1. **Nadia Comăneci's Achievements**:
   - Nadia Comăneci was the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 at the Olympic Games, achieving this feat at the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal.
   - She scored a total of 7 perfect 10s during the 1976 Olympics.
   - Comăneci won three gold medals, one silver medal, and one bronze medal at the same Olympics.

2. **Historical Context**:
   - The 1976 Olympics marked a significant moment in gymnastics history, as it was previously thought that a perfect score was unattainable.
   - Comăneci's performance contributed to establishing gymnastics as a prominent sport and showcased the potential for excellence in athletic performance.

3. **Impact on Gymnastics**:
   - Comăneci's achievements inspired future generations of gymnasts and changed the perception of what was possible in the sport.
   - Her success at the Olympics set a new standard for scoring and performance in gymnastics.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**:
   - The information illustrates a clear cause-and-effect relationship: Comăneci's rigorous training and skill led to her historic performances, which in turn influenced the sport of gymnastics and its scoring system.
   - By analyzing how her perfect scores resulted in multiple medals, the model can learn to identify patterns of achievement linked to specific actions (e.g., training, technique).

2. **Logical Inference**:
   - The model can infer that achieving a high level of performance (like scoring multiple perfect 10s) is likely to lead to recognition (medals, records).
   - The historical context allows the model to understand the significance of Comăneci's achievements beyond just numbers, recognizing the broader impact on the sport and future athletes.

3. **Pattern Recognition**:
   - The model can identify patterns in competitive success, such as the correlation between scoring high and winning medals, which can be applied to other contexts in sports or performance-based evaluations.

4. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - The timeline of events (training, competition, scoring) helps the model understand sequences and their implications, enhancing its ability to reason about events that unfold over time.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating the extracted information about Nadia Comăneci's achievements and their implications, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. This includes understanding relationships between actions and outcomes, recognizing patterns in performance, and applying these insights to broader contexts. Such enhancements can lead to more nuanced reasoning in various domains, including sports analytics, performance evaluation, and historical analysis.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
In 1976, which gymnast scored 7 maximum scores of 10 as she won three gold medals, one silver and one bronze?
answer:
Reasoning process:
To identify the gymnast who scored 7 maximum scores of 10 in 1976 and won three gold medals, one silver, and one bronze, we can analyze the context of gymnastics during that time. The 1976 Summer Olympics were held in Montreal, Canada, and were notable for the performances of several gymnasts.

Among the prominent gymnasts of the 1976 Olympics was Nadia Comăneci, a Romanian gymnast. She is famously known for being the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 in Olympic history. During the 1976 Olympics, she achieved this feat multiple times, totaling seven perfect 10 scores throughout the competition. 

Nadia Comăneci won three gold medals in the individual all-around, balance beam, and uneven bars, along with a silver medal in the team competition and a bronze medal on the floor exercise. 

Given this information, it is clear that Nadia Comăneci is the gymnast in question.

Answer:
Nadia Comăneci

To identify the gymnast who scored 7 maximum scores of 10 in 1976 and won three gold medals, one silver, and one bronze, we can analyze the context of gymnastics during that time, particularly focusing on the 1976 Summer Olympics held in Montreal, Canada. 

1. **Historical Context**: The 1976 Olympics were pivotal in gymnastics history, showcasing remarkable performances that changed the sport's landscape. Nadia Comăneci, a Romanian gymnast, emerged as a standout athlete during these Games.

2. **Nadia Comăneci's Achievements**:
   - Comăneci was the first gymnast to score a perfect 10 in Olympic history, achieving this milestone multiple times during the competition.
   - She scored a total of 7 perfect 10s throughout the 1976 Olympics, which was unprecedented at that time.
   - Her medal tally included three gold medals (individual all-around, balance beam, and uneven bars), one silver medal (team competition), and one bronze medal (floor exercise).

3. **Cause and Effect**:
   - The rigorous training and innovative techniques employed by Comăneci led to her historic performances. This causal relationship illustrates how dedication and skill can result in exceptional outcomes, such as winning multiple medals and setting records.
   - The impact of her performance extended beyond her personal achievements; it inspired future generations of gymnasts and established a new standard for excellence in the sport.

4. **Logical Inference**:
   - From Comăneci's achievements, we can infer that high performance in gymnastics is likely to lead to recognition and accolades. This understanding can be applied to analyze other athletes' performances and their outcomes in various sports.
   - The historical significance of her scores and medals provides a broader context for understanding the evolution of gymnastics scoring and the expectations placed on athletes.

5. **Pattern Recognition**:
   - The correlation between scoring high (perfect 10s) and winning medals is a pattern that can be recognized and analyzed. This pattern can help the model understand competitive success in other contexts, such as academic performance or artistic competitions.

6. **Temporal Reasoning**:
   - Understanding the sequence of events—training leading to competition, resulting in scoring and medal wins—enhances the model's ability to reason about events that unfold over time. This temporal aspect is crucial for analyzing performance trajectories in various fields.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating the extracted information about Nadia Comăneci's achievements and their implications, we can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. This includes understanding relationships between actions and outcomes, recognizing patterns in performance, and applying these insights to broader contexts.

### Answer:
Nadia Comăneci

question_info.question: In 1976, which gymnast scored 7 maximum scores of 10 as she won three gold medals, one silver and one bronze?
passages:
While training for the World Championships in Tokyo, Sacramone tore her Achilles tendon. She returned to the U.S. immediately for surgery. However, the team kept her name on the roster, and she was given a gold medal despite not competing. This gave her the most World Championships medals of any female American gymnast, with ten. Simone Biles would break that record in 2015.
There were only 4 routines left for each gymnast to compete. With 2 down and 2 to go the places were now: Gnauck 1st, Davydova 2nd, Shaposhnikova and Comaneci joint 3rd. Nadia Comăneci then scored a 10 on bars, the only gymnast to receive a perfect score that night. (It was her first perfect score on bars in a major competition since the 1976 Olympics). Neil Admur, New York Times, 25 July 1980, A17, "The drama on the final rotation added to the suspense. Miss Gnauck was second among the 9 gymnasts on the vault, Miss Davydova seventh on the bars and Miss Comaneci eight on the beam". Maxi Gnauck held the lead until her last routine when she vaulted insecurely. She scored 9.7, on a vault with a start value of 9.9, the same as she had scored for this vault at 1979 European Championships in Denmark and 79 World Championships in United States. Barry Lorge, Washington Post, 25 July 1980, p. 9, "Gnauck, first of the contenders up in the fourth and final rotation. Her first vault looked good but was too safe : 9.7. She knew she had to do better but she buckled on the landing of her second vault". Peter Aykroyd, International Gymnastics : Sport, Art or Science ?, 1987, p. 68, "She went into the all-round finals with a slight lead, but weak vaulting lost her this advantage".
A perfect 10 is a score of 10.00 for a single routine in artistic gymnastics, which was once thought to be unattainable—particularly at the Olympic Games—under the code of points set by the International Gymnastics Federation (FIG). It is generally recognized that the first person to score a perfect 10 at the Olympic Games was Romanian Nadia Comăneci, at the 1976 Games in Montreal. Other women who accomplished this feat at the Olympics include Nellie Kim, also in 1976, Mary Lou Retton in 1984, Daniela Silivaș and Yelena Shushunova in 1988, and Lavinia Miloșovici in 1992. The first man to score a perfect 10 is considered to be Alexander Dityatin, at the 1980 Olympics in Moscow. (However, in the 1924 Paris Olympics, 22 men achieved a mark of 10 in rope-climbing, with one Albert Séguin getting a second 10 in the sidehorse vault, events that are no longer part of artistic gymnastics.)
Maria Kondratyevna Gorokhovskaya (, ; 17 October 1921 – 22 July 2001) was a Soviet gymnast of Jewish descent. At the 1952 Summer Olympics, she won seven medals, the most medals won by any woman in a single Olympics.
Larisa Semyonovna Latynina (, ; née Diriy; born 27 December 1934) is a former Soviet artistic gymnast from southern Ukrainian SSR. Between 1956 and 1964 she won 14 individual Olympic medals and four team medals. She holds the record for the most Olympic gold medals by a gymnast, male or female, with 9. Her total of 18 Olympic medals was a record for 48 years. She held the record for individual event medals with 14 for 52 years. She is credited with helping to establish the Soviet Union as a dominant force in gymnastics.
Shannon Miller, who competed at the 1992 and 1996 Olympics, won seven total Olympic medals, the most of any American female gymnast. She won five medals in 1992 and added two more in 1996. Dominique Dawes competed at the 1992, 1996, and 2000 Olympics, winning four medals. Miller and Dawes were both members of the "Magnificent Seven", the 1996 team that became the first American squad to win the team all-around gold medal at the Olympics. The competition was highlighted by Kerri Strug sticking a vault while injured to ensure the U.S. victory.
Almost a quarter of all the medals and 25 of the gold ones were won in gymnastics, with Olympic and sport icon Nadia Comăneci becoming the first gymnast ever to score a perfect ten in an Olympic event at the 1976 Summer Olympics. 
She won all six rhythmic gymnastics events included as part of the gymnastics program at the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne. She joined Graham Smith (1978, Edmonton), Susie O'Neill (1998, Kuala Lumpur) and Ian Thorpe (2002, Manchester) as the only competitors to win six gold medals at a single Commonwealth Games.
Czechoslovakia's Věra Čáslavská won 11 total Olympic medals, the second-most of any female gymnast. She won one in 1960, four in 1964, and six in 1968. She won the individual all-around golds in 1964 and 1968. Nadia Comăneci, who competed for Romania in 1976 and 1980, won nine medals. In 1976, she became the first gymnast to earn a perfect 10 and eventually achieved that mark seven times during the Games. She also won the individual all-around gold that year.
The Magnificent Seven was the 1996 United States Olympic women's gymnastics team that won the first ever gold medal for the United States in the women's team competition at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The seven members of the team were Shannon Miller, Dominique Moceanu, Dominique Dawes, Kerri Strug, Amy Chow, Amanda Borden, and Jaycie Phelps. Miller, Dawes and Chow also won individual medals in Atlanta. The team is perhaps best known for Strug sticking the landing of a vault to clinch the gold medal while injured.
